transcript: Kind: captions Language: en for the past 365 days I've been investing $5 a day into the stock market every day and today I'm going to share exactly how much money I've made but first we have to back up a little bit because this isn't just some stupid challenge I made up for the sake of making content There's an actual reason and meaning behind this we all have bad habits I'm sure we'd love to quit don't lie I'm sure you do and you know how hard it can be for some of you it may be smoking for others it may be just ordering too much takeout food and me I have a bad habit I really wanted to quit but was having a really hard time letting go of so really this is a story of turning a bad habit into a good one because you see I have a morning routine except mine doesn't involve ice baths and meditation it involves daily stops at a convenience store on the way to work to buy one of these I am addicted to energy drinks and it's not even that I really need the jolt of caffeine most days it's just that they taste good and I got in the habit of having something flavorful to sip on as I began my workday but here's the thing there's no way these things can be healthy for you and on top of that they're pretty damn expensive too anywhere from $3 to $5 a can depending on which one I pull out of the cooler that day so not only do I have an unhealthy habit I'm looking to kick but a rather expensive one as well but just telling myself that I was going to stop and today was the day I was just going to drive by and continue on my way to work wasn't really working and I'm sure a lot of you are the same way but I am way more likely to do something if I'm incentivized to do it so in order to kick the bad habit of buying a Red Bull on the way to work every day I needed to give myself an incentive to stop so I decided to try to end one habit by starting another except I'd be turning a bad habit into a good one instead of spending all that money on an energy drink every morning I'd take it and invest it into the S&P 500 instead trust me I know it's one of the most worn out and repeated cliches in all of personal finance that if you only stopped buying Starbucks coffee every morning and invested that money instead that after 30 years you'd have a million dollars which while true from a purely mathematical standpoint is advice I absolutely hate and the reason I hate that advice so much is because quitting the little things that may bring you Joy isn't the way to build wealth it's much better better to focus your time and energy on the bigger wins in your financial life you could save yourself more money in 10 minutes of negotiating the price of your next car than you would in 2 years of skipping your morning coffees but here's the thing my Red Bull habit doesn't really bring me much joy it's not something that's making my life any better and it's not really something I want to continue doing it's just a bad habit I've fallen into and I'm kind of getting annoyed at how much money I waste on it so I decided I'm spending $3 to5 every day on these stupid things why don't I test out that old cliche and invest that money every day instead of buying the energy drinks that way not only do I have a healthier morning routine but I get a little bit richer in the process that's a win-win if I've ever seen one and if you're unfamiliar investing this way is called dollar cost averaging it's investing strategy where you don't time the highs or lows of the market you invest consistently through all the ups and downs of the market with the thought that at the end of the day all of that volatility and its impact on your portfolio evens out and in just a minute we'll jump inside my account and I'll show you exactly how much money I've made over the course of this challenge so far and you'll be able to see all of those ups and downs that the market took over the span of just a single year but first a little more about how I've structured this Challenge and we'll start with where I'm investing at and for this challenge I'm using a Robin Hood account and I chose Robin Hood mainly because I already had the account sitting there with no money in it doing nothing and Robin Hood has an automatic investing feature where I can set it up to pull $5 a day every day from my bank account and invest it into the S&P 500 automatically because those of you who know me and have watched my videos in the past know the more automated and hands-off you can keep your investing the more likely you'll stick with your plan and end up seeing success over the long run secondly why did I choose the S&P 500 and that part is simple the the S&P 500 is the gold standard as to what everyone else measures their Investments against when you hear an investor say they're trying to beat the market or an investor can't beat the market it's the S&P 500 they're using as that Benchmark for the market and to almost no one's surprise almost all investors who set out to beat the S&P 500 fail in the long run another important factor in choosing the S&P 500 and if you're someone who can only afford to invest smaller amounts of money at any given time this is important your money simply goes further when you're investing in a broad market index fund like the S&P 500 by investing in the S&P 500 or more specifically the ETF vo which I'm using for this challenge my money gets invested in apple Nvidia Amazon and all the other top companies you hear so much about I'm Diversified into a complete stock portfolio from my first $5 if I tried to build my own portfolio stocks on $5 a day it would take me a really long time to build a diversified portfolio with any sort of meaningful amount of money in any of those given stocks so now let's get into how much money I've actually made by investing $5 a day over the past year now it's also important to note the stock market isn't open 365 days a year and like I said I want to keep my investments simple and hands off so I didn't try to Tinker and make up for lost days where the market was closed for weekends or holidays or whatever else I only made my $5 Investments on open trading days for the stock market I made my first $5 investment on August 1st 2023 and 12 months later I had invested $1,250 of my own money which was good for a whopping 2.82 shares of the vo ETF and when we're talking about investing let's be real that number may not seem big at all but let's remember that number also represents the amount of money I would have spent buying energy drinks at the convenience store instead over that same time period so in that context $1,250 seems massive now my first purchase of the S&P 500 Index ETF vo was made at a price of $ 41922 and by dollar cost averaging every day over 12 months my average purchase price of all of those individual $5 Investments worked out to be $443 9 cents per share and there have been plenty of dips and bumps in the road along the way but the market has mostly gone up over the past year and at day 365 of this experiment vo was trading at a price of $563 per share $10.55 came from vo's dividends which were of course reinvested directly into more shares of VO to help with my compounding returns just look at the growth from my first dividend which was a whopping 75 to my most recent one of $464 and you can kind of see how that compounding works and another thing I really wanted to show with this experiment is that you don't need a ton of money to see the benefits of putting it to work in the stock market even a trivial sum of $5 per day can eventually grow into something worthwhile and my account which started at $0 365 days ago has grown to $1,432 54 a gain of 15 03 or just over $187 you can see from just the last year how the growth and the dividends both start to compound even when we're talking about small amounts of money and it's not bad when you consider the alternative the plan for now is to keep this experiment going and if you have any ideas for another experiment I can run alongside this definitely let me know in the comments below thanks for watching this video I hope you enjoyed it and I'll see you in the next one

along the way but the market has mostly gone up over the past year and at day 365 of this experiment vo was trading at a price of $563 per share $10.55 came from vo's dividends which were of course reinvested directly into more shares of VO to help with my compounding returns just look at the growth from my first dividend which was a whopping 75 to my most recent one of $464 and you can kind of see how that compounding works and another thing I really wanted to show with this experiment is that you don't need a ton of money to see the benefits of putting it to work in the stock market even a trivial sum of $5 per day can eventually grow into something worthwhile and my account which started at $0 365 days ago has grown to $1,432 54 a gain of 15 03 or just over $187 you can see from just the last year how the growth and the dividends both start to compound even when we're talking about small amounts of money and it's not bad when you consider the alternative the plan for now is to keep this experiment going and if you have any ideas for another experiment I can run alongside this definitely let me know in the comments below thanks for watching this video I hope you enjoyed it and I'll see you in the next one
summary:
A financial content creator demonstrated the power of consistent, small-scale investing by redirecting a daily $5 spending habit into the S&P 500 ETF (VOO) for one year. This experiment highlighted the effectiveness of **dollar-cost averaging**, the importance of **automating investments**, and the benefit of **immediate diversification** offered by broad market index funds like the S&P 500.

Over 12 months, a total investment of $1,250 yielded a 15.03% return, amounting to a $187.54 gain, with an additional $10.55 in reinvested dividends. The key insight is that significant capital is not a prerequisite to begin investing; even a seemingly "trivial" sum like $5 per day, consistently applied, can meaningfully accumulate and effectively leverage the power of compounding, proving a superior financial practice to discretionary spending.

transcript: Kind: captions Language: en inflation has slowed interest rates are peaking and you're wondering should I still be putting my money towards treasury bills and ibonds in this video I'll give you the answer to that question and let you in on my personal strategy for how much I'll be investing in t- bills and ibonds this year the draw to T bills over the past few years has been easy to explain there was a lot of instability and fear surrounding the economy and unlike stocks treasuries are completely safe investment backed by the full faith of the US government so as long as you hold your treasuries until maturity you're guaranteed not to lose any of the principle you put into them in the first place and investors have been craving that kind of safety the fact that t- bills have been paying record high interest rates on top of that only made them that much more appealing even now t- bells are yielding over 5.3% that's higher than even the best high yield savings accounts you'll find but we're in a different Market than we were in 2023 or 2022 stocks are soaring Bitcoin is at alltime highs and it generally feels like good times are here again so should you be putting your money into t- bills and locking in 5% when you could be buying a ticket to the moon and dumping that money into Bitcoin or Nvidia it's a legitimate question to ask yourself and I'll give you a few reasons why I think that t- bills and ibonds are still worth your time in 2024 as I sit here and record this we're in the middle of tax season I just filed my return last week and while it was nice earning a nice high interest rate on my savings account all year long it became a little less fun when I filed my taxes because as some of you may know I live in New York and any of that interest I earned on my high yield savings account over the course of the year is taxed not only by the federal government but by New York State as well and chances are you're in the same boat as I am because 41 out of the 50 states have a state income tax but if you invest that money in t- bills not only do you get a higher interest rate than high yield savings accounts are paying but any interest you earn on treasuries is exempt from state income taxes meaning the actual interest rate you're earning by putting your money in the treasuries is in reality that much higher than what you're earning on your high yield savings account and no matter who we are each one of us still has a need for safety in our portfolio Safety Not only from loss but from inflation and from changing interest rates because interest rates right now are the highest they've been at since around 2007 and all signs are pointing to this maybe being the highest they're going to get for a while the possibility is they may even decrease in the near future and I think that opens up a unique opportunity not only in TB bills but also with ibonds which we'll talk more about in a minute the opportunity we have in t- bills right now is that if this really is the highest interest rates are going to get for a long time we can lock them in right now and protect ourselves against the possibility of them falling over the course of this year because once you buy a t bill you lock in that interest rate that's what you're going to earn on that investment no matter what it's not like your high yield savings account where the second that the FED Cuts interest rates your bank is going to follow suit and cut the interest rate they're paying you on your money and the longer term T bill you buy buy better off you'll be if and when the FED does decide to start cutting interest rates later this year or maybe even in the next a one-year T bill is currently paying right around 5% so you can lock in a guaranteed 5% and no risk return on your money by buying a 12-month T bill when the probability is that a year from now interest rates are going to be significantly lower than 5% my only word of caution here is to be sure you weigh the length of T Bill you're going to buy against when you may need access to that money because while you can sell t- bills early before maturity I always advise buying a length that you'll be comfortable with holding the whole way through we should also be a little careful on playing predictions on where interest rates might go if they might go higher or lower in the future because that just like timing the stock market is a game none of us are going to win now in my case my wife is in the market for a new car so we're going to have to pull a good chunk of money out of our savings to pay for it whenever she makes up her mind and decides what is is she wants to drive so I'm going to need to have access us some money fairly quickly and I don't want to lock that money up in a one-year T Bill if I'm going to need it in 2 or 3 months so instead what I'm doing with my T Bill Investments right now is I'm putting them towards the shortest term t- bills available which of course are the 4-we t- Bills and a weird Quirk we have going on right now is the 4-we T bills are actually paying a higher interest rate than the oneyear t bills but remember and I have to point this out because I got a lot of comments on my prior t- Bill videos the interest rates quoted for t- bills are the annual ized interest rate so a 4-we t bill paying 5.3% you're not getting 5.3% in that 4 weeks you're getting 4 weeks of an annualized 5.3% interest on your money so just don't let that trip you up and you'll be fine another thing I got a lot of comments about in my prior t- Bill videos which you should watch if you haven't is that using the treasury direct website to buy them is really clunky and not user friendly so that's why I'm also trying out a new app made specifically summary:
Despite roaring equity and crypto markets, a financial analyst asserts that 2024 remains an excellent time to invest in Treasury Bills (T-Bills) and I-Bonds, as they provide essential portfolio safety, inflation protection, and the opportunity to lock in high interest rates before potential future declines.

**Treasury Bills (T-Bills)** are highlighted for their safety (U.S. government-backed, guaranteeing principal if held to maturity), attractive state tax-exempt yields (currently over 5.3% for shorter terms like 4-week, surpassing high-yield savings accounts), and the ability to lock in these potentially peaking rates. The speaker uses shorter-term T-Bills for liquidity, advising investors to align maturities with their cash needs, and recommends Finvest as an easy-to-use platform for purchases.

**I-Bonds** are now considered a "much better investment opportunity" for long-term holders due to a new, guaranteed 1.3% fixed interest rate, which ensures they will beat inflation for up to 30 years. This contrasts with previous I-Bonds that had a 0% fixed rate. The analyst advises strategically selling older 0% fixed-rate I-Bonds to repurchase new ones, even if it incurs a 3-month interest penalty. He plans to maximize his 2024 I-Bond allotment ($10,000 direct purchase + $5,000 via tax refund), delaying the tax refund portion until mid-April to potentially secure an even higher fixed rate for I-Bonds issued from May to October, noting their particular suitability for future expenses like education.

summary:
Despite roaring equity and crypto markets, a financial analyst asserts that 2024 remains an excellent time to invest in Treasury Bills (T-Bills) and I-Bonds, as they provide essential portfolio safety, inflation protection, and the opportunity to lock in high interest rates before potential future declines.

**Treasury Bills (T-Bills)** are highlighted for their safety (U.S. government-backed, guaranteeing principal if held to maturity), attractive state tax-exempt yields (currently over 5.3% for shorter terms like 4-week, surpassing high-yield savings accounts), and the ability to lock in these potentially peaking rates. The speaker uses shorter-term T-Bills for liquidity, advising investors to align maturities with their cash needs, and recommends Finvest as an easy-to-use platform for purchases.

**I-Bonds** are now considered a "much better investment opportunity" for long-term holders due to a new, guaranteed 1.3% fixed interest rate, which ensures they will beat inflation for up to 30 years. This contrasts with previous I-Bonds that had a 0% fixed rate. The analyst advises strategically selling older 0% fixed-rate I-Bonds to repurchase new ones, even if it incurs a 3-month interest penalty. He plans to maximize his 2024 I-Bond allotment ($10,000 direct purchase + $5,000 via tax refund), delaying the tax refund portion until mid-April to potentially secure an even higher fixed rate for I-Bonds issued from May to October, noting their particular suitability for future expenses like education.

summary:
Despite roaring equity and crypto markets, a financial analyst asserts that 2024 remains an excellent time to invest in Treasury Bills (T-Bills) and I-Bonds, as they provide essential portfolio safety, inflation protection, and the opportunity to lock in high interest rates before potential future declines.

**Treasury Bills (T-Bills)** are highlighted for their safety (U.S. government-backed, guaranteeing principal if held to maturity), attractive state tax-exempt yields (currently over 5.3% for shorter terms like 4-week, surpassing high-yield savings accounts), and the ability to lock in these potentially peaking rates. The speaker uses shorter-term T-Bills for liquidity, advising investors to align maturities with their cash needs, and recommends Finvest as an easy-to-use platform for purchases.

**I-Bonds** are now considered a "much better investment opportunity" for long-term holders due to a new, guaranteed 1.3% fixed interest rate, which ensures they will beat inflation for up to 30 years. This contrasts with previous I-Bonds that had a 0% fixed rate. The analyst advises strategically selling older 0% fixed-rate I-Bonds to repurchase new ones, even if it incurs a 3-month interest penalty. He plans to maximize his 2024 I-Bond allotment ($10,000 direct purchase + $5,000 via tax refund), delaying the tax refund portion until mid-April to potentially secure an even higher fixed rate for I-Bonds issued from May to October, noting their particular suitability for future expenses like education.

your treasuries until maturity you're guaranteed not to lose any of the principle you put into them in the first place and investors have been craving that kind of safety the fact that t- bills have been paying record high interest rates on top of that only made them that much more appealing even now t- bells are yielding over 5.3% that's higher than even the best high yield savings accounts you'll find but we're in a different Market than we were in 2023 or 2022 stocks are soaring Bitcoin is at alltime highs and it generally feels like good times are here again so should you be putting your money into t- bills and locking in 5% when you could be buying a ticket to the moon and dumping that money into Bitcoin or Nvidia it's a legitimate question to ask yourself and I'll give you a our savings to pay for it whenever she makes up her mind and decides what is is she wants to drive so I'm going to need to have access us some money fairly quickly and I don't want to lock that money up in a one-year T Bill if I'm going to need it in 2 or 3 months so instead what I'm doing with my T Bill Investments right now is I'm putting them towards the shortest term t- bills available which of course are the 4-we t- Bills and a weird Quirk we have going on right now is the 4-we T bills are actually paying a higher interest rate than the oneyear t bills but remember and I have to point this out because I got a lot of comments on my prior t- Bill videos the interest rates quoted for t- bills are the annual ized interest rate so a 4-we t bill paying 5.3% you're not getting 5.3% in that 4 weeks you're getting 4 weeks of an annualized 5.3% interest on your money so just don't let that trip you up and you'll be fine another thing I got a lot of comments about in my prior t- Bill videos which you should watch if you haven't is that using the treasury direct website to buy them is really clunky and not user friendly so that's why I'm also trying out a new app made specifically fixed interest rate above and beyond the inflation rate will be a real benefit to my savings goals like paying for kids college someday because ibonds become even more attractive when used for educ a costs if you want to know more about that and several other unique ways you can use ibonds that you may not have thought about before be sure to click on this video now thanks for watching and I hope to see you there
summary:
Despite roaring equity and crypto markets, a financial analyst asserts that 2024 remains an excellent time to invest in Treasury Bills (T-Bills) and I-Bonds, as they provide essential portfolio safety, inflation protection, and the opportunity to lock in high interest rates before potential future declines.

**Treasury Bills (T-Bills)** are highlighted for their safety (U.S. government-backed, guaranteeing principal if held to maturity), attractive state tax-exempt yields (currently over 5.3% for shorter terms like 4-week, surpassing high-yield savings accounts), and the ability to lock in these potentially peaking rates. The speaker uses shorter-term T-Bills for liquidity, advising investors to align maturities with their cash needs, and recommends Finvest as an easy-to-use platform for purchases.

**I-Bonds** are now considered a "much better investment opportunity" for long-term holders due to a new, guaranteed 1.3% fixed interest rate, which ensures they will beat inflation for up to 30 years. This contrasts with previous I-Bonds that had a 0% fixed rate. The analyst advises strategically selling older 0% fixed-rate I-Bonds to repurchase new ones, even if it incurs a 3-month interest penalty. He plans to maximize his 2024 I-Bond allotment ($10,000 direct purchase + $5,000 via tax refund), delaying the tax refund portion until mid-April to potentially secure an even higher fixed rate for I-Bonds issued from May to October, noting their particular suitability for future expenses like education.

summary:
M1 Finance has undergone significant changes, fundamentally altering its value proposition. Key positive shifts include the elimination of Payment for Order Flow (PFOF) by bringing trade execution in-house and making all M1 Plus features (such as multiple trading windows) free for users.

However, these improvements are coupled with challenges and a new fee structure. M1 discontinued its checking accounts and temporarily paused new high-yield savings account (HYSA) enrollments, failing to deliver promised "checking-like" features to the HYSA. Most notably, effective May 2024, a new $3/month platform fee will be introduced for accounts with a total combined balance under $10,000, effectively making M1 Plus features free only for those above this threshold. This fee is speculated to manage the cost of small accounts and maintain competitiveness.

As a result, M1 Finance is highly recommended for users who already have or can quickly accumulate $10,000 or more to invest, as its automated "pie" system for hands-off dollar-cost averaging remains excellent and the platform effectively becomes free for them. For investors starting with smaller amounts (e.g., under $10,000), the $3/month fee makes the value proposition "tricky." While M1's automation is valuable, the fee may erode returns for small balances, and free alternatives like Fidelity, Schwab, or Robinhood might be more suitable unless the user highly values M1's specific automation features.

summary:
M1 Finance has undergone significant changes, fundamentally altering its value proposition. Key positive shifts include the elimination of Payment for Order Flow (PFOF) by bringing trade execution in-house and making all M1 Plus features (such as multiple trading windows) free for users.

However, these improvements are coupled with challenges and a new fee structure. M1 discontinued its checking accounts and temporarily paused new high-yield savings account (HYSA) enrollments, failing to deliver promised "checking-like" features to the HYSA. Most notably, effective May 2024, a new $3/month platform fee will be introduced for accounts with a total combined balance under $10,000, effectively making M1 Plus features free only for those above this threshold. This fee is speculated to manage the cost of small accounts and maintain competitiveness.

As a result, M1 Finance is highly recommended for users who already have or can quickly accumulate $10,000 or more to invest, as its automated "pie" system for hands-off dollar-cost averaging remains excellent and the platform effectively becomes free for them. For investors starting with smaller amounts (e.g., under $10,000), the $3/month fee makes the value proposition "tricky." While M1's automation is valuable, the fee may erode returns for small balances, and free alternatives like Fidelity, Schwab, or Robinhood might be more suitable unless the user highly values M1's specific automation features.

summary:
M1 Finance has undergone significant changes, fundamentally altering its value proposition. Key positive shifts include the elimination of Payment for Order Flow (PFOF) by bringing trade execution in-house and making all M1 Plus features (such as multiple trading windows) free for users.

However, these improvements are coupled with challenges and a new fee structure. M1 discontinued its checking accounts and temporarily paused new high-yield savings account (HYSA) enrollments, failing to deliver promised "checking-like" features to the HYSA. Most notably, effective May 2024, a new $3/month platform fee will be introduced for accounts with a total combined balance under $10,000, effectively making M1 Plus features free only for those above this threshold. This fee is speculated to manage the cost of small accounts and maintain competitiveness.

As a result, M1 Finance is highly recommended for users who already have or can quickly accumulate $10,000 or more to invest, as its automated "pie" system for hands-off dollar-cost averaging remains excellent and the platform effectively becomes free for them. For investors starting with smaller amounts (e.g., under $10,000), the $3/month fee makes the value proposition "tricky." While M1's automation is valuable, the fee may erode returns for small balances, and free alternatives like Fidelity, Schwab, or Robinhood might be more suitable unless the user highly values M1's specific automation features.

Most notably, effective May 2024, a new $3/month platform fee will be introduced for accounts with a total combined balance under $10,000, effectively making M1 Plus features free only for those above this threshold. This fee is speculated to manage the cost of small accounts and maintain competitiveness.

As a result, M1 Finance is highly recommended for users who already have or can quickly accumulate $10,000 or more to invest, as its automated "pie" system for hands-off dollar-cost averaging remains excellent and the platform effectively becomes free for them. For investors starting with smaller amounts (e.g., under $10,000), the $3/month fee makes the value proposition "tricky." While M1's automation is valuable, the fee may erode returns for small balances, and free alternatives like Fidelity, Schwab, or Robinhood might be more suitable unless the user highly values M1's specific automation features.

summary:
M1 Finance has undergone significant changes, fundamentally altering its value proposition. Key positive shifts include the elimination of Payment for Order Flow (PFOF) by bringing trade execution in-house and making all M1 Plus features (such as multiple trading windows) free for users.

However, these improvements are coupled with challenges and a new fee structure. M1 discontinued its checking accounts and temporarily paused new high-yield savings account (HYSA) enrollments, failing to deliver promised "checking-like" features to the HYSA. Most notably, effective May 2024, a new $3/month platform fee will be introduced for accounts with a total combined balance under $10,000, effectively making M1 Plus features free only for those above this threshold. This fee is speculated to manage the cost of small accounts and maintain competitiveness.

As a result, M1 Finance is highly recommended for users who already have or can quickly accumulate $10,000 or more to invest, as its automated "pie" system for hands-off dollar-cost averaging remains excellent and the platform effectively becomes free for them. For investors starting with smaller amounts (e.g., under $10,000), the $3/month fee makes the value proposition "tricky." While M1's automation is valuable, the fee may erode returns for small balances, and free alternatives like Fidelity, Schwab, or Robinhood might be more suitable unless the user highly values M1's specific automation features.

summary:
A financial analyst's review of millionaire habits debunks common myths, revealing that wealth is primarily built through disciplined financial habits rather than high income, inheritance, or lavish spending. Key insights include:

*   **Frugality is Paramount:** Millionaires are disciplined spenders, with high percentages using grocery lists and coupons, demonstrating a consistent focus on cost control.
*   **Self-Made and Patient:** The vast majority (80%) are self-made, often from humble beginnings, achieving millionaire status typically after age 50, underscoring the importance of patience and consistent, long-term effort.
*   **Net Worth Trumps Income:** A significant portion of millionaires never earned over $100,000 annually, highlighting that effective income management and savings are more critical than high earnings alone.
*   **Strategic Living and Investing:** They actively live below their means, often owning only one modest home despite significant wealth. Furthermore, nearly 90% hold college degrees (with many having advanced degrees), and a substantial 80% leverage employer 401k plans, affirming the value of education and long-term, systematic investing as foundational wealth-building strategies.

summary:
A financial analyst's review of millionaire habits debunks common myths, revealing that wealth is primarily built through disciplined financial habits rather than high income, inheritance, or lavish spending. Key insights include:

*   **Frugality is Paramount:** Millionaires are disciplined spenders, with high percentages using grocery lists and coupons, demonstrating a consistent focus on cost control.
*   **Self-Made and Patient:** The vast majority (80%) are self-made, often from humble beginnings, achieving millionaire status typically after age 50, underscoring the importance of patience and consistent, long-term effort.
*   **Net Worth Trumps Income:** A significant portion of millionaires never earned over $100,000 annually, highlighting that effective income management and savings are more critical than high earnings alone.
*   **Strategic Living and Investing:** They actively live below their means, often owning only one modest home despite significant wealth. Furthermore, nearly 90% hold college degrees (with many having advanced degrees), and a substantial 80% leverage employer 401k plans, affirming the value of education and long-term, systematic investing as foundational wealth-building strategies.

summary:
The primary driver of significant wealth accumulation, including becoming a millionaire, is identified as **time and consistent investing**, rather than exceptional investment skill.

This insight is powerfully illustrated by contrasting Warren Buffett, a renowned skilled investor, with Ronald Read, a janitor. For Buffett, the video emphasizes that the vast majority (over 99%) of his immense fortune was accumulated after age 50, underscoring that his extraordinary wealth is a testament to the unparalleled power of compounding over an exceptionally long investment horizon, rather than solely his investment acumen. Conversely, Ronald Read, despite his modest earnings and lack of investment expertise, amassed over $8 million by simply and consistently investing small amounts into a diversified portfolio of understandable "Blue Chip stocks" and holding them for decades.

The overarching conclusion is that consistent, long-term investment, even with a simple strategy, can lead to substantial wealth. The video practically demonstrates this by showing how consistently maxing out a Roth IRA from age 18 to 60 could yield over $2 million, reinforcing the accessibility of wealth accumulation through patience and regularity.

summary:
The primary driver of significant wealth accumulation, including becoming a millionaire, is identified as **time and consistent investing**, rather than exceptional investment skill.

This insight is powerfully illustrated by contrasting Warren Buffett, a renowned skilled investor, with Ronald Read, a janitor. For Buffett, the video emphasizes that the vast majority (over 99%) of his immense fortune was accumulated after age 50, underscoring that his extraordinary wealth is a testament to the unparalleled power of compounding over an exceptionally long investment horizon, rather than solely his investment acumen. Conversely, Ronald Read, despite his modest earnings and lack of investment expertise, amassed over $8 million by simply and consistently investing small amounts into a diversified portfolio of understandable "Blue Chip stocks" and holding them for decades.

The overarching conclusion is that consistent, long-term investment, even with a simple strategy, can lead to substantial wealth. The video practically demonstrates this by showing how consistently maxing out a Roth IRA from age 18 to 60 could yield over $2 million, reinforcing the accessibility of wealth accumulation through patience and regularity.

title: How To Become A Millionaire on A Low Salary
description:
You can build lasting wealth no matter how much money you earn and there's one simple key to doing so. 

A janitor and the world's richest man may not seem like they have much in common. But the stories of Ronald Read and Warren Buffett hold the the key building wealth and becoming a millionaire no matter how much money you make.
